reviews.review: 10\10! GOTY of 2013 for me

Still playing as I write this but like the first Bioshock, this one's a master piece in its own! Graphics and the art are breathtaking at places! Really doubted them for a while to pull this one but the developers did not disappoint! I am glad I pre-ordered when I did :)
Воистину 10 из 10 !!! Прошел с огромным удовольствием! Хоть она и для одного игрока, но за нее не жалко отдать её стоимость!

Without question, one of the most awesome games in years. Gorgeously designed, loads of fun to play, with one of the best companion systems I've ever seen in a game. And the ending is a real mind-bender, far better than the usual kill-the-big-bad-guy-and-everything-okay. Truly fantastic!
Interesting story and fun to play, but it would have been a better game without the vigors.
was quite interesting, fairly fun... something different

Graphics can't save this game from its repetative, tedious and just boring combat, story was not bad, not satisfying though, but you will find youself just hoping the generic and just average combat ends so you can get on with the story, and walk through more beautiful non combat areas.  This is an 8/10 dont believe that 10/10 commercial its Bull.

Absolutely incredible, I bought it for full price and it was definitely worth it.  The game play is fantastic and fun, the environments and story are amazing, and the ending will likely leave your head spinning.

This game was FANTASTIC. I can't think of a better single-player experience I've had in recent years.

The world is lovingly crafted, that voice-acting superb, and the story expertly delivered. The gameplay is fun, but I wouldn't say especially amazing. What makes Bioshock: Infinite so great is that it is an  excellent storytelling experience. The gameplay is fun, but I really had to keep going in order to find out what would happen next in the plot. I just HAD to know. 

I hope that Infinite becomes a model for other single-player games in the future. If future games have even half the attention to detail that this game has, I'll be delighted.

All in all, highly recommend. One of the few times I would say I agree with the hyperbolistic 10/10 and 9.5/10 review grades out there.
要剧情有剧情，要挑战1999模式战个痛，要有趣各种技能武器加铁钩，伊丽莎白援助给力及时，59.99没有多人模式也花的值！
Would you kindly play this game.
Definatly worth the $60

Bioshock Infinite recebeu excelentes críticas, tem um dos maiores scores do metacritic. Estamos diante do melhor jogo da geração? Do Ano?  Ou apenas mais um jogo interessante onde as escolhas dos desenvolvedores  acabaram por limitar o potencial do mesmo?

Veremos a seguir.

Resumo da ópera: Bioshock Infinite tenta ser um dos mais ambiciosos jogos da geração e entrega um universo carismático, interessante e profundo, mas entrega também um FPS com vários problemas de mecânica, escolhas ruins e linearidade crescente conforme se progride no jogo. Deixando claro que o jogo foi apressado da metade para o final.

Quando somos inseridos em Colúmbia é assustador como aquele universo consegue nos transmitir uma pulsação, como aquele universo parece rico, vivo e variado. Até os trausentes são interessantes e você pode se interessar em ouvir as conversas alheias, observar  como uma cidade nas nuvens é bonita. Além do conteúdo ser completamente interessante, com suas escolhas, direção de arte e pesquisa. Tudo parece tão bem montado. Mas um jogo não é um filme e o gameplay e suas respectiva mecânica são tão importante quanto a ambientação.

Daí que Bioshock parece apenas um jogo médio. Não há mais estratégia de combate variada como nos anteriores, não há escolhas relevantes para o jogador como antes. Não importa o que o jogador faça, o final será o mesmo. Não é um problema de gênero, e sim um problema de artesanato. Criou-se um universo interessante, conteúdo com potência de ser grande, mas não se lapidou as arestas, não se projetou mapas para se explorar, não se aprofundou nas possibilidades da batalha( como um uso melhor de vigor com os tears). Inclusive, as armas são reflexos dessa falta de esmero para polir o jogo( simples e sem inovações, como um mundo onde exista vigors pode não haver munições variadas ou uso da tecnologia dos vigors no armamento). Sem falar de limitar o arsenal a duas armas, tirando qualquer possibilidade de planejamento mais profundo das táticas de batalha. No final, aquele universo interessante, aquele roteiro magistral com twist shakeasperiano mostra-se um jogo extremamente linear e scriptado.

O jogo é uma resolução opaca e estranha de um potencial que não se cumpre. Muito bom jogo, mas os desenvolvedores poderiam dar mais atenção no polimento do jogo. Entramos num restaurante caro e nos entregam um fast food onde deveria existir um refeição completa, nutritiva e saborosa.
GREAT GAME EVEN IF YOU HAVENT PLAYED THE OTHERS

Honestly, it's everything a video game should be, and more. It's challenging, engaging, engrossing, a feast for the eyes, and it'll keep you guessing until the very end. If you buy one game this year, make sure this is it.
Amazing story line!!! Quite short unless you dig around.

Overall, a worthy successor to it's namesakes. Truly excellent art direction and music, along with good writing and characterization. Admittedly it does suffer somewhat from the arbitrary two-weapon limit, regenerating shields, and less emphasis on resource management. But there's still plenty to enjoy here, and it's definitely worth your time.

What more can be said about Bioshock Infinite that hasn't been said already? Well, 'A step in the wrong direction' is a start. Coming on the heels of Bioshock and Bioshock 2 (which was indeed coming on the heels of System Shock and System Shock 2,) Infinite is comparable only in the combat, which is a carbon copy of the other Bioshock games. The guns really lack a realistic feel and damage seems to be arbitrary. The Vigors, formerly known as plasmids, have prettier skins, and only two or three are useful, but that's about it. All of the minigames are gone: lock picking has turned into a single button press which Elizabeth automatically does for you, provided you have a pick. Movement is clumsy, inventory is non-existent and I swear to God that stealth just doesn't work. The graphics are as good as they get (I hope you like blinding white lights) and the animations are top-notch. But honestly, no one cares, because no one plays Bioshock for gameplay. People play Bioshock for atmosphere. Unfortunately, here it's at an all time low for two reasons: the city and the girl.

Columbia is beautiful but shallow. Gone is the depressing, destroyed world of Rapture – which indeed seemed like a vibrant world at one point. When you first go to Columbia, you actually see what it's like on an average day and it... Is entirely empty. People are motionless and scripted. It never feels lived in; it always feels like a set piece. Even when it starts getting destroyed, stores look like they haven't been maintained in years, and houses don't even have rats living in them, nonetheless people. Some people praise this, as Columbia clearly can't exist in reality, but no one had these delusions that Rapture could be real either. In fact, a great deal of Bioshock 1 was spent exploring why Rapture was doomed to failure from the start. Colombia, on the other hand, is really just a cool locale and nothing more. It's Olde Timey for the sake of being Olde Timey, opposed to Rapture that had a Fritz Lang look to it because it was about the failures of a utopian society, especially one that ignores its laborers. Rapture as a city was a graveyard: a final resting place for Andrew Ryan's totalitarian Libertarianism and it's drug-addled residents. Columbia feels like someone put a dead body in a tuxedo and brought it to a dinner party, by comparison.

The other element that really damages the atmosphere is also it's greatest success: Elizabeth. She prevents the sense of dread that both the Bioshock and System Shock series are famous for, and because of her constant, although never annoying, presence you simply feel like you're trapped in The Land of the Crazies. Sure, it's interesting and fun, but you never get the feeling that you're the world's last hope for sanity, as you did in Bioshock 1, and your sanity is never thrown into question (This is why the surprise twist at the end of Bioshock 1 worked so well.) In addition, she frequently becomes the exposition and in all honestly, is a rather flat character. Both her and Booker see their fair share of tragedy, and surprisingly I was far more sympathetic to the terse, insensitive, protagonist than I was this clearly Lowest Common Denominator device to pull at my heartstrings. Sometimes she's as helpless as a little girl and sometimes she's as powerful as a demigod with no clear reasoning or development one way or the other. Her development screams of Hegel's self-actualizing introspection and ends up being the culmination of a Hegalian Absolutist Idealist nightmare. But I really don't want to get invested in the metaphysics. Technically speaking, she's mostly well written, her AI is tolerable and her facial expressions are phenomenal. She tends to pop around, which a fool might believe is a part of the commentary. I believe it's lazy path finding.

The Best Game I Have Ever Played.
Beautiful, enjoyable, captivating. I'll admit there was one time (close to the end) that I had to look at what was next. I didn't know about the 'show quest arrow' button.

I bet you won't find such deep mind and thoughts put into video game anywhere else. Good story, great characters, amazing narration. Game that makes you think, only intelligent one since first Bioshock

A near-perfect game that has been expertly crafted by the crew at Irrational. It feels like a Bioshock game without being a re-tread. The story is LOST levels of confusing-stupid-great, but it's entertaining. Gameplay is fun and frantic. The city of Colombia is absolutely stunning, and is up there with Half-Life 2's City 17 as far as atmosphere of a fictional city goes in gaming. 

10 out of 10

This game is an excellent work of art...  If you can get past the stuff that sucks.  The graphics are good, the environments are absolutely stunning, the world is awesome, and the story is one of the best ever told.  BUT...  The combat sucks.  Vigors (basically the most popular Plasmids from Bioshock 1 with different names) could have saved it in some way, but they simply don't.  You run out of salts too quickly and none are really useful enough to even be worth using.  So then the combat becomes shooting people with generic guns.  There were many times when I wanted to enjoy the game so much that I almost did, but in reality, I was despising every moment and even getting a little bored.  Luckily this didn't happen often enough to make this a bad game.  In fact, I would still call it one of the best games I've ever played, but just keep in mind that the combat only serves as a distraction from the good.

FIne game. This is one of the few games to include a sidekick that actually helps you out and doesn't weigh the player down, so thats a big plus. The mechanics are all fine, no problems there except with the vigors. Some vigors are pretty useless and one is almost impossible to use right (I talk of Return to Sender, crappy vigor). The story is way more involved than the first two games, instead of a society built upon a single political ideal, infinite introduces alternate dimensional stuff which ties into the story in a very strange way. I'm still not sure I understand it. This game is proof that the Bioshock franchise might not die a horrible drawn out death like what EA did to Command & Conquer (may it rest it peace) and I hope that the developers don't fuck it up, Bioshock 2 was too close to being a dud.

9/10

Cons:
- Gameplay is limited to 2 weapons at a time, if it's going to be limited I really would have liked 3
- Powers are mostly the same as Bioshock (which makes sense, but still...)

Pros:
- Everything else

Lots of little complaints I won't bother to mention, but overall this was a fantastic game, and if the rave reviews all over the internet haven't convinced you to buy it yet you're a terrible person.

Edit/update May 2015: Still great.

Игра завораживает с первых минут, яркие цвета, отличная графика и анимация персонажей, сюжет оригинальный и заставляет работать мозг, представлять все это, геймплей по началу трудно дается, но потом ты к нему привыкаешь и понимаешь насколько он удобен на самом деле.

Highly anticipated game. This game sucked me right in from the start. They have created a really nice atmosphere in this one. At least the first half of the game. Unfortunately, the atmosphere changes and the change in environment makes you forget you're in a city in the clouds. Parts of it feels more like the city in Dishonored. I would have prefered if they kept the blue skies, fluffy clouds and the feeling of being up in the air throughout the game, but considering the story, I can see why the blue skies is not a good option.

At the end of the day, this is a really good game in spirit with the first two BioShock games. They could have made the plasmids more interesting though. It also shows signs of being a console port. Saving system is awful, you can only carry two guns (!) and a few techical issues. And personally I found the woman accompanying you a bit annoying at certain points. I prefer being the lone hero.

Good story, great gunplay and nice visuals. It's a great game allthough I prefer BioShock 1 and 2 over this one.

The flying city of Columbia is certainly a step in the other direction from the usual deep-sea Rapture, and not just in terms of location.

While the first two games both take place in the once beautiful underwater paradise of Rapture, but after years of civil war and rampant splicing among the citizens that managed to survive, the Rapture Jack and Delta find is a broken down collection of rusted metal and super-powered psychos in formal attire. In Columbia; the citizens are still cheerful and greet everyone with a smile, the city itself is as clean and pristine as the day it ascended up into the clouds, and the Great Prophet Comstock watches over his flock pure white with an all-seeing eye.

The city isn't all that's new; gone is the old tried and tested weapon and health systems, instead, Infinite tries to hang with other big-boy FPS titles by striping away the stockpile of Medkits and Salts (EVE) and weapon wheel, and replacing them with a shield and ONLY 2 WEAPONS AT ANY GIVEN TIME. Although ammo and upgrades do carry over even if said weapon isn't equipped at the time, the need for having more than 2 weapons makes itself blatantly apparent when coming fresh out of an encounter with a small army of Vox, only to get ambushed by a Handyman (Big Daddy/Big Sister) and his Fireman (Brute Splicer that's on fire) buddy. Suddenly, that Machine Gun/Carbine combo is just as effective as using a BB gun against an angry rhino. The Sky Hook, the wrench/drill's replacement, plays a double roll, in being both a melee weapon and the means in which to rapidly explore Columbia via Sky-Line...not to mention give the game its "M" rating by allowing the execution of weakened enemies (neck-snapping, ripping up their chests, grinding it into their necks before casting them aside, and full-on squeezing their heads till they pop).

The way Vigors (Plasmids) are acquired is a mixed blessing; while Vigors can be upgraded in different ways, one can only FIND them (not that that's a bad thing) as there are no Gather's Gardens. The upsides to this are that ADAM (no equivalent) is never an issue as everything is bought with Silver Eagles (Columbia's currency) and each Vigor can be charged up to create its own unique trap. The game does compensate by giving larger payouts while looting through bodies and various containers. Pieces of gear are found in the same way as Gene Tonics in the first two games, only now they can be dropped by killing a Handyman as there is a lack of a Research Camera and Gene Banks. The only way to change gear is when acquiring a piece that goes in that same slot (of which there are 4: hats, waist coats, pants, and shoes) and seeing which one is more is going to be more useful in the long run as another piece of the same slot may not present itself for some time (EDIT: Turns out "O" is the default inventory button and allows you to change your gear at any given time, not that there's any indication).

All in all; Bioshock Infinite is an amazing game that, while making some unnecessary and ultimately stupid design choices, still lives up to what a Bioshock game aspires to be...and the ending made my head explode rainbows of "WHAAAAAAAAAT?", but in a good way.

Wonderful visual, Solid gameplay, Mind-blowing storytelling, what else is needed?

Beautiful, thrilling, immersive.
I had to play and finish it 3 times because i wanted to enjoy every detail.
And i would play it again without a doubt.
I still think that the 1st BioShock was "better" mostly because at that time i couldn't believe such an incredible game could exist, and this one is the perfect piece to continue that legacy.
The only thing i didn't like so much is the fact that you don't need so much preparation before a fight, in BS 1 and 2 you needed to set lots of traps and find good spots to fight only 1 Big Daddy, here (even in 1999 mode) you can pretty much run into any scenario and fight without using any traps. Maybe the skyrails are the element that allows that to happen.
Either way, amazing game, one of the best stories I've ever experienced in videogames or even book reading... 
You don't need to play the first games, but you will miss a lot of great elements of the story...

UPDATE 2014: Going throught my 4th playthrough, just because after BAS Ep. 2 i felt really nostalgic and i wanted to go back to "happier" times in the story...
Even after so many hours of playing this game i keep finding little details and things around the different scenarios, thank you and thank you again to all the people that participated in the creation of this beautiful game and story.

The story kept me guessing right to the end.

Pretty neat game, but really should not have been called Bioshock. It lacks the thematic plot elements, atmosphere, game style...Actually, the only thing that it has in common with any of the previous games is the structure of progression: here's a door you can't get through so look around in this general area to open it up repeated ad nauseum.

Otherwise, it stands up strongly. The level design is usually the strongest point; the places you fight have really interesting geometry. Along with the aggressive enemy AI, it forces the player to move and think quickly, but also allows lots of fun ways to navigate said terrain (strongly punctuated by the skyhook mechanic). Fighting itself is really entertaining, despite they guns being generally boring. There's a wide variety of firearms, but half of them are Vox Populi remixes of ideas you've already seen for the first half of the game with Founder weapons. The powers are slightly better, but range from being similarly samey to indicative of laziness.

It's a great game overall. The atmosphere is top-notch and the narrative is pretty bold for an AAA game (your mileage may vary with its impact), but just don't play it expecting anything from previous [variable]shock games.

Simply a work of art. Bioshock Infinite represents the apex of the first person shooter revolution started by Half-Life so many years ago. I truly envy those who get to experience this game for the first time.

Irrational Games has raised the bar for story-driven first person shooters to the heights of Columbia itself.

There are no words that even come close to describing what I have just played. All these reviews, all these 10/10 scores, I thought it was just marketing in order to drum up more sales, but I was wrong. 

The combat was smooth and crisp, the voice acting always on key. The setting and backdrops were something to drool over. You didn't just want to stare at them, you wanted to feel them. With the combination of the excellent lighting, and ambient sounds you really almost could. 

The story was ,I hate to say it being so cliche, like a roller coaster, although not in a traditional sense. The story kept building and building and building, then at the end you were swept off of your feet not knowing where you were. This game should not be played only once, it deserves far more than that.

Video games take you into other worlds to escape reality, but this takes you inward into the depths of your very soul. In the end I found something greater than reality...something...infinite.
The best game ever (really) amazing story and soundtrack and everything!

This game has been so hyped that it actually overshadows the excellent quality of this game. It is an improvement over the original two Bioshocks (from what small amount I played) making the aspects of the game more meaningful to the player bringing a tad of the old challenging consequence back from how it was in System Shock 2 for things such as deaths costing you money and skills being upgradable without a chance to reset them (from what I've seen so far). The story is inspired and fleshed out, feeling very streamlined and progressive, with a wonderfully detailed and thought-out setting. The gameplay is tight, smooth, and pleasantly crafted in it's own style. I haven't had such a fun experiance in a single-player fps/rpg in a long time and this might be one of the best games to come out in the last few years, imo. I'd definately pick this game up. 9/10 
Btw, I played through the entire game and played a good portion of it before posting this review so ignore the amount played it shows.
Excellent game. One of the few that was worthy of the hype.
Absolutely amazing game. Perhaps even better than the first, because they fixed everything that they didn't manage to have in the game correctly the first time around.

Mindblowing story in something as simple as a firstperson shooter.
I loved it!
Amazing, get this now.
THIS GAME IS SO GOOD VARIOUS FLUIDS LEAKED OUT OF ME WHILST I PLAYED AND I DIDN'T CARE SO I JUST KEPT ON PLAYING AND LEAKING AND IT WAS GLORIOUS.
Одна из самых лучших игр этого года!

Personally, I don't consider this an actual Bioshock title, but it is an amazing game nonetheless.  The reason I do not consider Infinite a Bioshock game is because I don't get any feel that I had from the first game. This game is more action than thriller, and there's nothing horrifying about this game. My final conclusion, though, is this is definitely worth playing through, and it'll surely make any shooter/action fan happy. 9/10

The story is far more enjoyable than the game play itself and the ending will make your brain hurt
but that said the story is SO DAMN GOOD that it's worth it

Greatest shooter of all time... It is a difficult thing to consider. I have played many shooters (Half-Life 1&2, FEAR, S.T.A.L.K.E.R., Crysis, Bioshock, Deus Ex, System Shock 2, and many others) and they are all simply fantastic games. But Bioshock Infinite... it is above everything else. The setting is so fresh and inovative. Not only is it a beauty to look at but it adds to the gameplay. On the topic of gameplay, this game nailed it. The weapons, abilities, melee, and sky-hook fights are always exciting and I only wanted more. The enemies are challenging and the 'bosses' are very unique and interesting, each one requiring a different approach to overcome. The graphics, while not technically the best (but still no slouch), are a feast for the eyes. But the big draw to Bioshock Infinite is the story and Elizabeth. Your mind will be blown by this game and you will wish so much that you could just experience it for the first time over and over. Buy this, do not get it in a deal, pay the top amount and make sure that Irrational Games gets as much money as they deserve every bit. Bioshock Infinite has replaced Crysis as my favorite shooter of all time and it has replaced Planescape: Torment as my favorite game of all time.

Easiest 5/5 ever.

This game is amzing and it throws you into the world of columia so well with the graphics, sound, voice acting and animations. God this game is amazing. Fupping hell, it's fantastic. 9.5/10
I never saw such an beautiful and impressive ambiance. It is not a game, it is arts. Even if you don't play shooters you should have seen this one.
Bioshock remains one of my favorite franchises.  All 3 games are great.  This one is right on par with the first game.

This game Is one of the more astonishing games I've played in recent time. What I loved about it, would be the atmosphere, sounds, and of course the very complex storyline. What I didn't like, was the lack of gun customization, and that the game only has about 6-7 guns In total. The lack of Vigors (laziness) also known as Plasmids from Bioshock 1-2. And the notion that Elizabeth throws you money every time you exit a vending machine (Complete Bollocks). I've spent about 20 hours playing the campaign on the hardest difficulty, and I must say It was a great experience. The voice acting combined with the world Columbia, the story and the interaction defo deserves 8/10 Gold Star. I would recommend this game If you like adventure, action and atmosphere.
Truly a great game. If you like story-driven games, then this is definitely for you!
